questions.question: Which colleges tend to have a lower tuition?

questions.title: Private vs. Public Institutions
questions.description: In-state public institutions tend to be more affordable than private institutions, the reason being that public institutions are funded by the government. However, public institutions can be as much as private institutions for out-of-state students.

questions.question: If your family makes under $65,000, a college like Harvard would be out of your price range.

questions.title: Shoot Your Shot!
questions.description: Apply to top schools that may seem our of your price range! Many have a large sum of money set aside specially for financial aid. Many schools like Harvard are need-blind and will provide full scholarships for families making less than $65,000.

questions.question: What does it mean for a college to be need-blind?

choices.answer: A college is blind to your physical needs
A college looks for at how much you can financially contribute
A college when looking at your application won't know your financial need
A college will ask you your needs during your application

questions.question: What are some financial aid applications to apply to?

choices.answer: FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid)

questions.title: FAFSA
questions.description: FAFSA is a free application to qualify for US citizens to get financial aid - filling this out determines how much money you can get. Be sure to fill it out right away when the application opens on October 1st every year.

questions.title: CSS Profile
questions.description: CSS Profile is another financial aid application ($25 for initial application, $16 per added college) that consists of non-federal grants. Make sure to fill this out in addition to the FAFSA because it will consider you for a school's financial aid.

questions.question: How many scholarships should I apply to?

questions.title: Scholarships
questions.description: Google scholarships! There are large scale scholarships such as the Gates Foundation, Coca-Cola Scholar Foundation, and the National Merit Scholarship Program. There are also ones that are more unique and specific to your identity and location.

choices.answer: US Department of Labor's free scholarship search tool
Your employer or your parent's employers

questions.question: Where can I get find the best student loans?

questions.title: Student Loans
questions.description: College loans are tough. Something to consider is to have a third party find you the most affordable loans. HSA Tutoring has partnered with Juno to help with this: joinjuno.com/p/hsatutoring

questions.question: Summary: What are ways to make college more affordable? (Select all that apply)

choices.answer: Apply to in-state public colleges and shoot your shot!
Find as many scholarships as you can and apply
Look for student loans that are affordable
